Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Translator: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Hello, my name is Christian Rudder, and I was one of the founders of OkCupid. It's now one of the biggest
dating sites in the United States. Like most everyone at the site,
I was a math major, As you may expect, we're known
for the analytic approach we take to love. We call it our matching algorithm. Basically, OkCupid's matching
algorithm helps us decide whether two people should go on a date. We built our entire business around it. Now, algorithm is a fancy word, and people like to drop it
like it's this big thing. But really, an algorithm
is just a systematic, step-by-step way to solve a problem. It doesn't have to be fancy at all. Here in this lesson, I'm going to explain how we arrived
at our particular algorithm, so you can see how it's done. Now, why are algorithms even important? Why does this lesson even exist? Well, notice one very significant
phrase I used above: they are a step-by-step
way to solve a problem, and as you probably know, computers
excel at step-by-step processes. A computer without an algorithm is basically an expensive paperweight. And since computers are such
a pervasive part of everyday life, algorithms are everywhere. The math behind OkCupid's matching
algorithm is surprisingly simple. It's just some addition, multiplication,
a little bit of square roots. The tricky part in designing it was figuring out how to take
something mysterious, human attraction, and break it into components
that a computer can work with. The first thing we needed
to match people up was data, something for the algorithm to work with. The best way to get data quickly
from people is to just ask for it. So we decided that OkCupid
should ask users questions, stuff like, "Do you want
to have kids one day?" "How often do you brush your teeth?" "Do you like scary movies?" And big stuff like,
"Do you believe in God?" Now, a lot of the questions
are good for matching like with like, that is, when both people
answer the same way. For example, two people
who are both into scary movies are probably a better match
than one person who is and one who isn't. But what about a question like, "Do you like to be
the center of attention?" If both people in a relationship
are saying yes to this, they're going to have massive problems. We realized this early on, and so we decided we needed
a bit more data from each question. We had to ask people to specify
not only their own answer, but the answer they wanted
from someone else. That worked really well. But we needed one more dimension. Some questions tell you more
about a person than others. For example, a question
about politics, something like, "Which is worse:
book burning or flag burning?" might reveal more about someone
than their taste in movies. And it doesn't make sense
to weigh all things equally, so we added one final data point. For everything that OkCupid asks you, you have a chance to tell us
the role it plays in your life. And this ranges
from irrelevant to mandatory. So now, for every question,
we have three things for our algorithm: first, your answer; second, how you want someone else --
your potential match -- to answer; and third, how important
the question is to you at all. With all this information, OkCupid can figure out
how well two people will get along. The algorithm crunches the numbers
and gives us a result. As a practical example, let's look at how we'd match you
with another person. Let's call him "B." Your match percentage with B is based
on questions you've both answered. Let's call that set
of common questions "s." As a very simple example,
we use a small set "s" with just two questions in common, and compute a match from that. Here are our two example questions. The first one, let's say, is,
"How messy are you?" And the answer possibilities are: very messy, average and very organized. And let's say you answered
"very organized," and you'd like someone else
to answer "very organized," and the question is very important to you. Basically, you're a neat freak. You're neat, you want someone else
to be neat, and that's it. And let's say B is a little bit different. He answered "very organized" for himself, but "average" is OK with him
as an answer from someone else, and the question is only
a little important to him. Let's look at the second question,
from our previous example: "Do you like to be
the center of attention?" The answers are "yes" and "no." You've answered "no," you want
someone else to answer "no," and the question is only
a little important to you. Now B, he's answered "yes." He wants someone else to answer "no," because he wants the spotlight on him, and the question is somewhat
important to him. So, let's try to compute all of this. Our first step is, since we use
computers to do this, we need to assign numerical values to ideas like "somewhat
important" and "very important," because computers need
everything in numbers. We at OkCupid decided
on the following scale: "Irrelevant" is worth 0. "A little important" is worth 1. "Somewhat important" is worth 10. "Very important" is 50. And "absolutely mandatory" is 250. Next, the algorithm makes
two simple calculations. The first is: How much did
B's answers satisfy you? That is, how many possible points
did B score on your scale? Well, you indicated that B's answer
to the first question, about messiness, was very important to you. It's worth 50 points and B got that right. The second question is worth only 1, because you said
it was only a little important. B got that wrong, so B's answers were 50
out of 51 possible points. That's 98% satisfactory. Pretty good. The second question the algorithm
looks at is: How much did you satisfy B? Well, B placed 1 point on your answer
to the messiness question and 10 on your answer to the second. Of those 11, that's 1 plus 10,
you earned 10 -- you guys satisfied each other
on the second question. So your answers were 10 out of 11
equals 91 percent satisfactory to B. That's not bad. The final step is to take
these two match percentages and get one number for the both of you. To do this, the algorithm
multiplies your scores, then takes the nth root, where "n" is the number of questions. Because s, which is the number
of questions in this sample, is only 2, we have: match percentage
equals the square root of 98 percent times 91 percent. That equals 94 percent. That 94 percent is your match
percentage with B. It's a mathematical expression
of how happy you'd be with each other, based on what we know. Now, why does the algorithm multiply, as opposed to, say, average
the two match scores together, and do the square-root business? In general, this formula
is called the geometric mean. It's a great way to combine
values that have wide ranges and represent very different properties. In other words, it's perfect
for romantic matching. You've got wide ranges and you've got
tons of different data points, like I said, about movies, politics,
religion -- everything. Intuitively, too, this makes sense. Two people satisfying
each other 50 percent should be a better match
than two others who satisfy 0 and 100, because affection needs to be mutual. After adding a little correction
for margin of error, in the case where we have
a small number of questions, like we do in this example, we're good to go. Any time OkCupid matches two people, it goes through the steps
we just outlined. First it collects data about your answers, then it compares your choices
and preferences to other people's in simple, mathematical ways. This, the ability to take
real-world phenomena and make them something
a microchip can understand, is, I think, the most important skill
anyone can have these days. Like you use sentences
to tell a story to a person, you use algorithms
to tell a story to a computer. If you learn the language,
you can go out and tell your stories. I hope this will help you do that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why does the algorithm multiply as opposed to average the two match scores together?
Options: A. The geometric mean, B. The pythagorean theorem, C. Algorithmic conductivity, D. All of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of OkCupid's matching algorithm? Options: A. To provide users with friendship suggestions, B. To help users find job matches, C. To decide whether two people should go on a date, D. To analyze user data for marketing purposes Correct Option: None
Question 2: What does the term "algorithm" refer to in the context of OkCupid's matching system? Options: A. A complex mathematical formula, B. A systematic, step-by-step way to solve a problem, C. A type of computer software, D. A statistical analysis technique Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why are algorithms important in everyday life? Options: A. Because they are used in medical research, B. Because they are used in financial analysis, C. Because computers excel at step-by-step processes and algorithms are used to tell a story to a computer, D. Because they are used in social media platforms Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of math is used in OkCupid's matching algorithm? Options: A. Calculus and differential equations, B. Addition, multiplication, and square roots, C. Statistics and probability, D. Algebra and geometry Correct Option: None

To collect more data for the algorithm, C. To improve the accuracy of matches, D. To reduce the number of questions asked Correct Option: None

The geometric mean is a type of average, and it is used to combine values with wide ranges and represent different properties., B. The geometric mean is a type of statistical analysis, and it is used to reduce the number of questions asked., C. The geometric mean is a type of mathematical formula, and it is used to increase user engagement., D. The geometric mean is a type of algorithm, and it is used to provide users with personalized recommendations. Correct Option: None

To provide users with more personalized recommendations, D. To make the algorithm more complex Correct Option: None

The algorithm averages the two match scores together and takes the square root., C. The algorithm adds the two match scores together and takes the square root., D. The algorithm subtracts the two match scores together and takes the square root. Correct Option: None

Translator: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Hello, my name is Christian Rudder, and I was one of the founders of OkCupid. It's now one of the biggest
dating sites in the United States. Like most everyone at the site,
I was a math major, As you may expect, we're known
for the analytic approach we take to love. We call it our matching algorithm. Basically, OkCupid's matching
algorithm helps us decide whether two people should go on a date. We built our entire business around it. Now, algorithm is a fancy word, and people like to drop it
like it's this big thing. But really, an algorithm
is just a systematic, step-by-step way to solve a problem. It doesn't have to be fancy at all. Here in this lesson, I'm going to explain how we arrived
at our particular algorithm, so you can see how it's done. Now, why are algorithms even important? Why does this lesson even exist? Well, notice one very significant
phrase I used above: they are a step-by-step
way to solve a problem, and as you probably know, computers
excel at step-by-step processes. A computer without an algorithm is basically an expensive paperweight. And since computers are such
a pervasive part of everyday life, algorithms are everywhere. The math behind OkCupid's matching
algorithm is surprisingly simple. It's just some addition, multiplication,
a little bit of square roots. The tricky part in designing it was figuring out how to take
something mysterious, human attraction, and break it into components
that a computer can work with. The first thing we needed
to match people up was data, something for the algorithm to work with. The best way to get data quickly
from people is to just ask for it. So we decided that OkCupid
should ask users questions, stuff like, "Do you want

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar At birth, our bodies are roughly 75% water. We remain mostly water for the rest of our lives. We cannot survive even a week without fresh water. There's no life without it for ecosystems, societies, and individuals. So, how much usable water is there on Earth? Most of the water on Earth is ocean, a salty 97.5%, to be precise, and the remaining 2.5% is fresh water. That little sliver of liquid sustains human life on Earth, it literally holds up civilizations. 2.5% is a small proportion to be sure, and even that is broken down into smaller parts: surface water, water in ice caps and polar regions, and ground water. First, surface water. All the liquid water above ground is surface water and it is a tiny blip of an amount. 0.3% of all fresh water is surface water. It may seem counterintuitive, but it accounts for little streams all over the planet. All rivers, including the Nile, the Jordan, and the Mississippi, and lakes, large to small, like Victoria, the Great Lakes, and Baikal. Second, ice caps and polar regions freeze up to 70% of the planet's fresh water. This water is significant, but it isn't available for human use in a regular way. Finally, nearly 30% of all water on Earth is ground water. As the name suggests, that's water in the ground. It can rest still and deep in huge caverns, or it can snuggle in the little crevices of rock and pebble. The upshot - thank goodness for ground water! It's invisible to us, but it is much more plentiful than surface water. It is much more reliable and easier to obtain than frozen water. Without ground water, our societies would be parched. So, how are we using that water? As a result of industrialization and population growth, demand for fresh water skyrocketed in the last century. Where is all that water going? First, we have to remember that fresh water is a global concern, but it is always local. Context matters. The Sahara is not Seattle. Still, some general information can help us get a handle on major trends. Who consumes the most fresh water? And, what sectors consume the most fresh water? First, who. Well, the United States consumes the most water per capita of any country in the entire world, followed by parts of Europe and large industrializing nations like China. But, this doesn't tell us what water is being used for. So let's look at it another way. If we ask what kinds of uses water is going towards, we see a different picture. Agriculture accounts for roughly 70% of global fresh water consumption. Again, remember the numbers vary by region, but still, it's a staggering amount. And, this makes a certain kind of sense: we need to eat, we need water to grow food; the bigger the population, the more food we need; and, the wealthier we get, the more meat we eat, and the more water is required to produce our food. Furthermore, 22% of all fresh water worldwide goes to industrial uses. This includes the production of electricity, the extraction of fossil fuels, and the manufacturing of all manner of goods, from microchips, to paper, to blimps. 70% to agriculture, 22% to industrial uses, what's left? 8% All those domestic uses - cooking, cleaning, bathing, drinking - it's a drop in the bucket of overall water use.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At birth, ______ of our bodies are made of water.
Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of water makes up the human body at birth? Options: A. 50%, B. 60%, C. 75%, D. 90% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of the Earth's water is freshwater? Options: A. 0.5%, B. 2.5%, C. 5%, D. 10% Correct Option: None
Question 3: What percentage of freshwater is surface water? Options: A. 0.1%, B. 0.3%, C. 1%, D. 3% Correct Option: None
Question 4: Where is approximately 70% of the planet's freshwater stored? Options: A. Oceans, B. Ice caps and polar regions, C. Groundwater, D. Surface water Correct Option: None
Question 5: What percentage of freshwater is groundwater? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which country consumes the most water per capita in the world? Options: A. China, B. United States, C. Australia, D. Canada Correct Option: None
Question 7: What sector accounts for approximately 70% of global freshwater consumption? Options: A. Industry, B. Agriculture, C. Domestic use, D. Energy production Correct Option: None
Question 8: What percentage of freshwater is used for industrial purposes? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 22%, D. 30% Correct Option: None
Question 9: What percentage of freshwater is used for domestic purposes? Options: A. 5%, B. 8%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main reason for the increased demand for freshwater in the last century? Options: A. Climate change, B. Population growth and industrialization, C. Urbanization, D. Deforestation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "What percentage of water makes up the human body at birth?" 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the percentage of water in the human body at birth. The options for Question 1 also include the correct answer, 75%, which is the same as the correct option in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 2

This includes the production of electricity, the extraction of fossil fuels, and the manufacturing of all manner of goods, from microchips, to paper, to blimps. 70% to agriculture, 22% to industrial uses, what's left? 8% All those domestic uses - cooking, cleaning, bathing, drinking - it's a drop in the bucket of overall water use.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 2.5%, B. 4.0%, C. 5.5%, D. 0.75%
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar At birth, our bodies are roughly 75% water. We remain mostly water for the rest of our lives. We cannot survive even a week without fresh water. There's no life without it for ecosystems, societies, and individuals. So, how much usable water is there on Earth? Most of the water on Earth is ocean, a salty 97.5%, to be precise, and the remaining 2.5% is fresh water. That little sliver of liquid sustains human life on Earth, it literally holds up civilizations. 2.5% is a small proportion to be sure, and even that is broken down into smaller parts: surface water, water in ice caps and polar regions, and ground water. First, surface water. All the liquid water above ground is surface water and it is a tiny blip of an amount. 0.3% of all fresh water is surface water. It may seem counterintuitive, but it accounts for little streams all over the planet. All rivers, including the Nile, the Jordan, and the Mississippi, and lakes, large to small, like Victoria, the Great Lakes, and Baikal. Second, ice caps and polar regions freeze up to 70% of the planet's fresh water. This water is significant, but it isn't available for human use in a regular way. Finally, nearly 30% of all water on Earth is ground water. As the name suggests, that's water in the ground. It can rest still and deep in huge caverns, or it can snuggle in the little crevices of rock and pebble. The upshot - thank goodness for ground water! It's invisible to us, but it is much more plentiful than surface water. It is much more reliable and easier to obtain than frozen water. Without ground water, our societies would be parched. So, how are we using that water? As a result of industrialization and population growth, demand for fresh water skyrocketed in the last century. Where is all that water going? First, we have to remember that fresh water is a global concern, but it is always local. Context matters. The Sahara is not Seattle. Still, some general information can help us get a handle on major trends. Who consumes the most fresh water? And, what sectors consume the most fresh water? First, who. Well, the United States consumes the most water per capita of any country in the entire world, followed by parts of Europe and large industrializing nations like China. But, this doesn't tell us what water is being used for. So let's look at it another way. If we ask what kinds of uses water is going towards, we see a different picture. Agriculture accounts for roughly 70% of global fresh water consumption. Again, remember the numbers vary by region, but still, it's a staggering amount. And, this makes a certain kind of sense: we need to eat, we need water to grow food; the bigger the population, the more food we need; and, the wealthier we get, the more meat we eat, and the more water is required to produce our food. Furthermore, 22% of all fresh water worldwide goes to industrial uses. This includes the production of electricity, the extraction of fossil fuels, and the manufacturing of all manner of goods, from microchips, to paper, to blimps. 70% to agriculture, 22% to industrial uses, what's left? 8% All those domestic uses - cooking, cleaning, bathing, drinking - it's a drop in the bucket of overall water use.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The world's fresh water is divided into three categories. Which is not one of those categories?
Options: A. Polar regions, B. Resevoirs, C. Ground Water, D. Surface Water
Correct Option: B

Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar At birth, our bodies are roughly 75% water. We remain mostly water for the rest of our lives. We cannot survive even a week without fresh water. There's no life without it for ecosystems, societies, and individuals. So, how much usable water is there on Earth? Most of the water on Earth is ocean, a salty 97.5%, to be precise, and the remaining 2.5% is fresh water. That little sliver of liquid sustains human life on Earth, it literally holds up civilizations. 2.5% is a small proportion to be sure, and even that is broken down into smaller parts: surface water, water in ice caps and polar regions, and ground water. First, surface water. All the liquid water above ground is surface water and it is a tiny blip of an amount. 0.3% of all fresh water is surface water. It may seem counterintuitive, but it accounts for little streams all over the planet. All rivers, including the Nile, the Jordan, and the Mississippi, and lakes, large to small, like Victoria, the Great Lakes, and Baikal. Second, ice caps and polar regions freeze up to 70% of the planet's fresh water. This water is significant, but it isn't available for human use in a regular way. Finally, nearly 30% of all water on Earth is ground water. As the name suggests, that's water in the ground. It can rest still and deep in huge caverns, or it can snuggle in the little crevices of rock and pebble. The upshot - thank goodness for ground water! It's invisible to us, but it is much more plentiful than surface water. It is much more reliable and easier to obtain than frozen water. Without ground water, our societies would be parched. So, how are we using that water? As a result of industrialization and population growth, demand for fresh water skyrocketed in the last century. Where is all that water going? First, we have to remember that fresh water is a global concern, but it is always local. Context matters. The Sahara is not Seattle. Still, some general information can help us get a handle on major trends. Who consumes the most fresh water? And, what sectors consume the most fresh water? First, who. Well, the United States consumes the most water per capita of any country in the entire world, followed by parts of Europe and large industrializing nations like China. But, this doesn't tell us what water is being used for. So let's look at it another way. If we ask what kinds of uses water is going towards, we see a different picture. Agriculture accounts for roughly 70% of global fresh water consumption. Again, remember the numbers vary by region, but still, it's a staggering amount. And, this makes a certain kind of sense: we need to eat, we need water to grow food; the bigger the population, the more food we need; and, the wealthier we get, the more meat we eat, and the more water is required to produce our food. Furthermore, 22% of all fresh water worldwide goes to industrial uses. This includes the production of electricity, the extraction of fossil fuels, and the manufacturing of all manner of goods, from microchips, to paper, to blimps. 70% to agriculture, 22% to industrial uses, what's left? 8% All those domestic uses - cooking, cleaning, bathing, drinking - it's a drop in the bucket of overall water use.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar About 100 days ago, we landed a two-ton SUV
on the surface of another planet, on the surface of Mars. This is one of the first pictures
we took there with our rover, looking out at Mount Sharp. I kind of cry a little bit, choke up, when I see this picture. Why Mars and why do we look
at these other planets? Part of it is to understand
our own planet -- what's the context for us? We live on this amazing planet,
but Mars is a lot like Earth. It's similar in size. During the daytime, it can
get up to 70 degrees Fahrenheit. So, it's so like Earth,
but at the same time, this is a barren landscape. You don't see any trees,
you don't see any cactuses growing, anything like that. Today I'm going to tell you
about how we got from Earth to Mars and why it's so cool. So one of the things we start with
is a blank sheet of paper. We knew from the previous missions
in 2004, Spirit and Opportunity, there was water on Mars in the past. But what's the next step? We're looking for an even more
fundamental level of, what does it take to have life survive? And so, to have that kind
of knowledge and understanding, we have to carry
a mass amount of instruments. We have to carry the kind of labs that people have whole rooms
devoted to on Earth inside of, essentially, a small car. And we shrunk it all down to something that weighs
about as much as I do, and then put it inside of this rover
that weighs as much as your car does. And that rover is now
on the surface of Mars, but it's so heavy, and so it kind of takes
a special challenge for us to make it all work and come together. So we look at our tool of,
what do we have to land stuff on Mars? And one of the options is airbags. We've done it before. Airbags are pretty cool,
they bounce around a lot. You could never put a human
inside of an airbag, because they would get squashed. But the problem with airbags is,
the airbags you see here, which landed the smaller rover --
it's like 400 pounds, the entire rover -- were about the size of this room. So you can imagine the size
of airbags it would take to land a two-ton rover on Mars. And they'd have to be made
out of materials that don't even exist today, so it'd be some kind of exotic material
that we'd have to develop and it may or may not work. So, what about rockets? You know, you see all the rocket ships
landing in old movies, all rockets on the bottom --
it's a cool idea. It works when they're pretty light still, but the problem is, these rockets
have to be pretty strong to actually softly land you on Mars. And so they would be so powerful
they could dig holes into the ground and then you would just
end up inside of a hole and not be able to drive out of it. So, not the best design. But what if I could take the rockets
and move them up? And that's what we came up with. It's a rocket-powered jet pack;
we call it the Sky Crane. Basically, this big rocket
sits on top of our rover and when we're ready to land,
the rocket hovers in place and we slowly lower
the rover to the ground. And then we touch down,
we're actually on the wheels, we're ready to drive, day one. But in addition to that,
the scientists were like, "We actually want to go
somewhere interesting." The last two missions were cool, but they basically landed in what was like
landing in the plains or desert. Not very exciting. We all know from the exciting places
on Earth like the Grand Canyon, those are, for the scientists,
the most interesting, because you see that whole layer, you see years and years
of history all in one place. The same thing is true
for where we landed. We wanted to land somewhere
that was unique, that had this crater wall
where things had been dug up for us, where mountains were pushing things up. But the problem is, if you landed
with the older systems, you could've landed on the side
of that mountain and just tumbled off, could've been the side of a cliff,
the crater wall or a large boulder. So we needed a kind of technology to help us land in a very small area, and that was this little
guided entry from Apollo. We took it from the 1960s. We flew over like the manned vehicle,
because they have to pick up men, you can't just land all over the place. And then we landed, like,
spot-on in the middle. And in fact, it was so spot-on
that when we did it, it was basically like a quarterback
launching towards Mars -- like a quarterback, though,
that was in Seattle, throwing at a receiver that was moving
here in Giants Stadium. That's how accurate we were.
Kind of awesome. But you only get one shot, and so we actually have to design a system that we can build and test and operate, and so it's not just about
can we get it to Mars, but, if it's only one chance, how do you make sure
that one chance goes well? So there's all these processes
to make sure things are built properly. Then we go out to the desert
and drive around and test it. We fly things in F-18s to make sure
the radar systems work in high speeds. Then, most importantly, we test the team
to make sure they know how to operate it. We don't want to miss it
because we sent the wrong command and now it's going
to be rebooting forever. So, that guy Fred there,
he did a lot of that. And then we launched it
on this rocket to Mars. We landed 2,000 pounds on Mars, but the entire thing
was about 10,000 pounds when we lifted off from Earth, all the fuel and the solar arrays
and everything else that we needed. And, again, we were so accurate that we landed in this, like,
little pin-point on Mars. In the meantime, though, we had to design
a landing system that worked. And I told you about the actual physics
of it, but here's the catch: Mars is about 14 minutes
away from Earth in light speed, which means if I try
to control it with a joystick, I would be always controlling
to 14 minutes in advance, so it wouldn't work. So we had to give it all the smarts
and knowledge it needed to make it happen. So we built in all these
smarts and algorithms and told it here's what
you're going to have to do, and it goes from basically
five times the speed of a speeding bullet to about a baby's crawl, all within about seven minutes, which are called
the seven minutes of terror, because I was about to throw up. (Laughter) But today we're on the surface of Mars,
and this was one of the panoramas we took a couple days after we landed, and it's amazing to me,
because you look at this, and can see the Grand Canyon, you can see your own planet,
you can imagine walking on the surface. And so what we're going to do
and continue to do is to understand
what makes Mars so special and what makes Earth even more special that we're all here together today. So we'll see where Curiosity takes us -- not just our rover, but our sense of exploration. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Approximately how much does Curiosity weigh?
Options: A. 500 pounds, B. 1 ton, C. 1.5 tons, D. 2 tons
Correct Option: D

They used a rocket-powered jet pack called the Sky Crane, C. They created a massive shock-absorbing system, D. They used a combination of airbags and rockets Correct Option: None

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 8: What was the total weight of the Curiosity rover and its supporting systems when it lifted off from Earth? Options: A. 2,000 pounds, B. 5,000 pounds, C. 10,000 pounds, D. 20,000 pounds**

Although this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the weight of the Curiosity rover itself, it is the closest match in terms of content and intent. The ground truth MCQ asks about the weight of the rover, while Question 8 asks about the total weight of the rover and its supporting systems. However, the transcript mentions that the rover itself weighs about 2 tons (which is approximately 4,000 pounds), and the total weight of the rover and its supporting systems is about 10,000 pounds.

The other generated MCQs do not match the ground truth MCQ as closely, either in terms of content or intent. Therefore, I recommend:

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar About 100 days ago, we landed a two-ton SUV
on the surface of another planet, on the surface of Mars. This is one of the first pictures
we took there with our rover, looking out at Mount Sharp. I kind of cry a little bit, choke up, when I see this picture. Why Mars and why do we look
at these other planets? Part of it is to understand
our own planet -- what's the context for us? We live on this amazing planet,
but Mars is a lot like Earth. It's similar in size. During the daytime, it can
get up to 70 degrees Fahrenheit. So, it's so like Earth,
but at the same time, this is a barren landscape. You don't see any trees,
you don't see any cactuses growing, anything like that. Today I'm going to tell you
about how we got from Earth to Mars and why it's so cool. So one of the things we start with
is a blank sheet of paper. We knew from the previous missions
in 2004, Spirit and Opportunity, there was water on Mars in the past. But what's the next step? We're looking for an even more
fundamental level of, what does it take to have life survive? And so, to have that kind
of knowledge and understanding, we have to carry
a mass amount of instruments. We have to carry the kind of labs that people have whole rooms
devoted to on Earth inside of, essentially, a small car. And we shrunk it all down to something that weighs
about as much as I do, and then put it inside of this rover
that weighs as much as your car does. And that rover is now
on the surface of Mars, but it's so heavy, and so it kind of takes
a special challenge for us to make it all work and come together. So we look at our tool of,
what do we have to land stuff on Mars? And one of the options is airbags. We've done it before. Airbags are pretty cool,
they bounce around a lot. You could never put a human
inside of an airbag, because they would get squashed. But the problem with airbags is,
the airbags you see here, which landed the smaller rover --
it's like 400 pounds, the entire rover -- were about the size of this room. So you can imagine the size
of airbags it would take to land a two-ton rover on Mars. And they'd have to be made
out of materials that don't even exist today, so it'd be some kind of exotic material
that we'd have to develop and it may or may not work. So, what about rockets? You know, you see all the rocket ships
landing in old movies, all rockets on the bottom --
it's a cool idea. It works when they're pretty light still, but the problem is, these rockets
have to be pretty strong to actually softly land you on Mars. And so they would be so powerful
they could dig holes into the ground and then you would just
end up inside of a hole and not be able to drive out of it. So, not the best design. But what if I could take the rockets
and move them up? And that's what we came up with. It's a rocket-powered jet pack;
we call it the Sky Crane. Basically, this big rocket
sits on top of our rover and when we're ready to land,
the rocket hovers in place and we slowly lower
the rover to the ground. And then we touch down,
we're actually on the wheels, we're ready to drive, day one. But in addition to that,
the scientists were like, "We actually want to go
somewhere interesting." The last two missions were cool, but they basically landed in what was like
landing in the plains or desert. Not very exciting. We all know from the exciting places
on Earth like the Grand Canyon, those are, for the scientists,
the most interesting, because you see that whole layer, you see years and years
of history all in one place. The same thing is true
for where we landed. We wanted to land somewhere
that was unique, that had this crater wall
where things had been dug up for us, where mountains were pushing things up. But the problem is, if you landed
with the older systems, you could've landed on the side
of that mountain and just tumbled off, could've been the side of a cliff,
the crater wall or a large boulder. So we needed a kind of technology to help us land in a very small area, and that was this little
guided entry from Apollo. We took it from the 1960s. We flew over like the manned vehicle,
because they have to pick up men, you can't just land all over the place. And then we landed, like,
spot-on in the middle. And in fact, it was so spot-on
that when we did it, it was basically like a quarterback
launching towards Mars -- like a quarterback, though,
that was in Seattle, throwing at a receiver that was moving
here in Giants Stadium. That's how accurate we were.
Kind of awesome. But you only get one shot, and so we actually have to design a system that we can build and test and operate, and so it's not just about
can we get it to Mars, but, if it's only one chance, how do you make sure
that one chance goes well? So there's all these processes
to make sure things are built properly. Then we go out to the desert
and drive around and test it. We fly things in F-18s to make sure
the radar systems work in high speeds. Then, most importantly, we test the team
to make sure they know how to operate it. We don't want to miss it
because we sent the wrong command and now it's going
to be rebooting forever. So, that guy Fred there,
he did a lot of that. And then we launched it
on this rocket to Mars. We landed 2,000 pounds on Mars, but the entire thing
was about 10,000 pounds when we lifted off from Earth, all the fuel and the solar arrays
and everything else that we needed. And, again, we were so accurate that we landed in this, like,
little pin-point on Mars. In the meantime, though, we had to design
a landing system that worked. And I told you about the actual physics
of it, but here's the catch: Mars is about 14 minutes
away from Earth in light speed, which means if I try
to control it with a joystick, I would be always controlling
to 14 minutes in advance, so it wouldn't work. So we had to give it all the smarts
and knowledge it needed to make it happen. So we built in all these
smarts and algorithms and told it here's what
you're going to have to do, and it goes from basically
five times the speed of a speeding bullet to about a baby's crawl, all within about seven minutes, which are called
the seven minutes of terror, because I was about to throw up. (Laughter) But today we're on the surface of Mars,
and this was one of the panoramas we took a couple days after we landed, and it's amazing to me,
because you look at this, and can see the Grand Canyon, you can see your own planet,
you can imagine walking on the surface. And so what we're going to do
and continue to do is to understand
what makes Mars so special and what makes Earth even more special that we're all here together today. So we'll see where Curiosity takes us -- not just our rover, but our sense of exploration. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is not an option for landing a large vehicle on Mars?
Options: A. Airbags, B. Rockets, C. Sky Crane, D. Parachutes
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason for exploring Mars and other planets? Options: A. To understand the context of our own planet, B. To search for extraterrestrial life, C. To develop new technologies, D. To mine resources Correct Option: None
Question 2: How does the temperature on Mars compare to Earth during the daytime? Options: A. It's much hotter, B. It's much colder, C. It's similar, reaching up to 70 degrees Fahrenheit, D. It's unpredictable Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the next step in the Mars exploration mission after discovering water on Mars in 2004? Options: A. Searching for signs of life, B. Studying the Martian atmosphere, C. Understanding what it takes to have life survive, D. Mapping the Martian terrain Correct Option: None
Question 4: How did the team manage to land a two-ton rover on Mars without using airbags or traditional rockets? Options: A. They developed a new type of parachute, B. They used a rocket-powered jet pack called the Sky Crane, C. They created a massive shock-absorbing system, D. They used a combination of airbags and rockets Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the main challenge in designing the landing system for the Curiosity rover? Options: A. Ensuring a soft landing, B. Avoiding obstacles on the Martian surface, C. Compensating for the 14-minute delay in communication with Earth, D. Managing the rover's weight Correct Option: None
Question 6: What technology did the team use to help the rover land in a very small area on Mars? Options: A. GPS navigation, B. Laser guidance, C. Guided entry from the Apollo era, D. Terrain mapping Correct Option: None
Question 7: How accurate was the landing of the Curiosity rover on Mars? Options: A. Within a few miles of the target site, B. Within a few hundred feet of the target site, C. Spot-on, like a quarterback throwing a touchdown pass, D. Not very accurate, missing the target site by a significant margin Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the total weight of the Curiosity rover and its supporting systems when it lifted off from Earth? Options: A. 2,000 pounds, B. 5,000 pounds, C. 10,000 pounds, D. 20,000 pounds Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the term used to describe the seven-minute period during which the Curiosity rover slowed down from five times the speed of a speeding bullet to a baby's crawl? Options: A. The seven minutes of terror, B. The Mars landing sequence, C. The rocket-powered descent, D. The Sky Crane maneuver Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of the Curiosity rover mission on Mars? Options: A. To search for signs of life, B. To study the Martian geology, C. To understand what makes Mars special and what makes Earth special, D. To prepare for human exploration of Mars Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: How did the team manage to land a two-ton rover on Mars without using airbags or traditional rockets?

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it discusses the options for landing a large vehicle on Mars. Although the question phrasing is different, the content and intent are similar. The correct option in Question 4 is B. They used a rocket-powered jet pack called the Sky Crane, which is similar to option C in the ground truth MCQ.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. The closest match would be a question that asks which option is NOT a method for landing a large vehicle on Mars, with options that include airbags, rockets, Sky Crane, and another option that is not a valid method.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would choose Question 4, but with the understanding that it's not an exact match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar About 100 days ago, we landed a two-ton SUV
on the surface of another planet, on the surface of Mars. This is one of the first pictures
we took there with our rover, looking out at Mount Sharp. I kind of cry a little bit, choke up, when I see this picture. Why Mars and why do we look
at these other planets? Part of it is to understand
our own planet -- what's the context for us? We live on this amazing planet,
but Mars is a lot like Earth. It's similar in size. During the daytime, it can
get up to 70 degrees Fahrenheit. So, it's so like Earth,
but at the same time, this is a barren landscape. You don't see any trees,
you don't see any cactuses growing, anything like that. Today I'm going to tell you
about how we got from Earth to Mars and why it's so cool. So one of the things we start with

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Though the actual Curiosity rover weighed much less, how much did the entire rocket (which included the rover) weigh at the time of take off?
Options: A. 10,000 pounds, B. 5,000 pounds, C. 3,500 pounds, D. 500 pounds
Correct Option: A

Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar About 100 days ago, we landed a two-ton SUV
on the surface of another planet, on the surface of Mars. This is one of the first pictures
we took there with our rover, looking out at Mount Sharp. I kind of cry a little bit, choke up, when I see this picture. Why Mars and why do we look
at these other planets? Part of it is to understand
our own planet -- what's the context for us? We live on this amazing planet,
but Mars is a lot like Earth. It's similar in size. During the daytime, it can
get up to 70 degrees Fahrenheit. So, it's so like Earth,
but at the same time, this is a barren landscape. You don't see any trees,
you don't see any cactuses growing, anything like that. Today I'm going to tell you
about how we got from Earth to Mars and why it's so cool. So one of the things we start with
is a blank sheet of paper. We knew from the previous missions
in 2004, Spirit and Opportunity, there was water on Mars in the past. But what's the next step? We're looking for an even more
fundamental level of, what does it take to have life survive? And so, to have that kind
of knowledge and understanding, we have to carry
a mass amount of instruments. We have to carry the kind of labs that people have whole rooms
devoted to on Earth inside of, essentially, a small car. And we shrunk it all down to something that weighs
about as much as I do, and then put it inside of this rover
that weighs as much as your car does. And that rover is now
on the surface of Mars, but it's so heavy, and so it kind of takes
a special challenge for us to make it all work and come together. So we look at our tool of,
what do we have to land stuff on Mars? And one of the options is airbags. We've done it before. Airbags are pretty cool,
they bounce around a lot. You could never put a human
inside of an airbag, because they would get squashed. But the problem with airbags is,
the airbags you see here, which landed the smaller rover --
it's like 400 pounds, the entire rover -- were about the size of this room. So you can imagine the size
of airbags it would take to land a two-ton rover on Mars. And they'd have to be made
out of materials that don't even exist today, so it'd be some kind of exotic material
that we'd have to develop and it may or may not work. So, what about rockets? You know, you see all the rocket ships
landing in old movies, all rockets on the bottom --
it's a cool idea. It works when they're pretty light still, but the problem is, these rockets
have to be pretty strong to actually softly land you on Mars. And so they would be so powerful
they could dig holes into the ground and then you would just
end up inside of a hole and not be able to drive out of it. So, not the best design. But what if I could take the rockets
and move them up? And that's what we came up with. It's a rocket-powered jet pack;
we call it the Sky Crane. Basically, this big rocket
sits on top of our rover and when we're ready to land,
the rocket hovers in place and we slowly lower
the rover to the ground. And then we touch down,
we're actually on the wheels, we're ready to drive, day one. But in addition to that,
the scientists were like, "We actually want to go
somewhere interesting." The last two missions were cool, but they basically landed in what was like
landing in the plains or desert. Not very exciting. We all know from the exciting places
on Earth like the Grand Canyon, those are, for the scientists,
the most interesting, because you see that whole layer, you see years and years
of history all in one place. The same thing is true
for where we landed. We wanted to land somewhere
that was unique, that had this crater wall
where things had been dug up for us, where mountains were pushing things up. But the problem is, if you landed
with the older systems, you could've landed on the side
of that mountain and just tumbled off, could've been the side of a cliff,
the crater wall or a large boulder. So we needed a kind of technology to help us land in a very small area, and that was this little
guided entry from Apollo. We took it from the 1960s. We flew over like the manned vehicle,
because they have to pick up men, you can't just land all over the place. And then we landed, like,
spot-on in the middle. And in fact, it was so spot-on
that when we did it, it was basically like a quarterback
launching towards Mars -- like a quarterback, though,
that was in Seattle, throwing at a receiver that was moving
here in Giants Stadium. That's how accurate we were.
Kind of awesome. But you only get one shot, and so we actually have to design a system that we can build and test and operate, and so it's not just about
can we get it to Mars, but, if it's only one chance, how do you make sure
that one chance goes well? So there's all these processes
to make sure things are built properly. Then we go out to the desert
and drive around and test it. We fly things in F-18s to make sure
the radar systems work in high speeds. Then, most importantly, we test the team
to make sure they know how to operate it. We don't want to miss it
because we sent the wrong command and now it's going
to be rebooting forever. So, that guy Fred there,
he did a lot of that. And then we launched it
on this rocket to Mars. We landed 2,000 pounds on Mars, but the entire thing
was about 10,000 pounds when we lifted off from Earth, all the fuel and the solar arrays
and everything else that we needed. And, again, we were so accurate that we landed in this, like,
little pin-point on Mars. In the meantime, though, we had to design
a landing system that worked. And I told you about the actual physics
of it, but here's the catch: Mars is about 14 minutes
away from Earth in light speed, which means if I try
to control it with a joystick, I would be always controlling
to 14 minutes in advance, so it wouldn't work. So we had to give it all the smarts
and knowledge it needed to make it happen. So we built in all these
smarts and algorithms and told it here's what
you're going to have to do, and it goes from basically
five times the speed of a speeding bullet to about a baby's crawl, all within about seven minutes, which are called
the seven minutes of terror, because I was about to throw up. (Laughter) But today we're on the surface of Mars,
and this was one of the panoramas we took a couple days after we landed, and it's amazing to me,
because you look at this, and can see the Grand Canyon, you can see your own planet,
you can imagine walking on the surface. And so what we're going to do
and continue to do is to understand
what makes Mars so special and what makes Earth even more special that we're all here together today. So we'll see where Curiosity takes us -- not just our rover, but our sense of exploration. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ferdowsi's team had to "build-in all these smarts and algorithms" in order to account for what he called the seven minutes of terror. For what exactly were they adjusting?
Options: A. Curiosity is moving so fast, Earth actually loses it for a little less than ten minutes, B. The amount of time it takes the landing gear to unfold once it has broken Mars' atmosphere, C. Mars is 14 minutes away (in light years) from Earth, D. The time it takes Curiosity to report back to mission control any unforeseen weather conditions on Mars' surface
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the oldest living single-cell microscopic organisms on the earth?
Options: A. Microbes, B. Bacteria, C. Fleas, D. Atoms
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are bacteria, and how long have they been on Earth? Options: A. Bacteria are multicellular organisms that have been on Earth for millions of years., B. Bacteria are single-celled microscopic organisms that have been on Earth for billions of years., C. Bacteria are single-celled organisms that have been on Earth for thousands of years., D. Bacteria are multicellular organisms that have been on Earth for billions of years. Correct Option: None
Question 2: How do bacteria make a living? Options: A. They consume nutrients from the environment, grow to twice their size, and then shrink back down., B. They consume nutrients from the environment, grow to twice their size, cut themselves down in the middle, and one cell becomes two., C. They consume nutrients from the environment and remain the same size., D. They produce their own nutrients and grow to twice their size. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the approximate ratio of bacterial cells to human cells in the human body? Options: A. 1:1, B. 10:1, C. 1:10, D. 100:1 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the bacterium that has a special property of making light? Options: A. Vibrio fischeri, B. Escherichia coli, C. Staphylococcus aureus, D. Bacillus subtilis Correct Option: None
Question 5: How do bacteria communicate with each other? Options: A. Through a complex system of nerves, B. Through a chemical language, C. Through sound waves, D. Through electromagnetic signals Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the process by which bacteria communicate with each other and coordinate their behavior? Options: A. Quorum sensing, B. Chemotaxis, C. Symbiosis, D. Mutualism Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the purpose of the molecule produced by Vibrio fischeri? Options: A. To attract predators, B. To communicate with other bacteria, C. To produce light, D. To defend against competitors Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the squid that has a symbiotic relationship with Vibrio fischeri? Options: A. Hawaiian bobtail squid, B. Giant squid, C. Colossal squid, D. Market squid Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the purpose of the anti-quorum sensing molecules developed by the researcher? Options: A. To promote the growth of beneficial bacteria, B. To inhibit the growth of pathogenic bacteria, C. To enhance the virulence of bacteria, D. To disrupt the communication between bacteria Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential application of the anti-quorum sensing molecules? Options: A. Development of new antibiotics, B. Development of new vaccines, C. Development of new diagnostic tools, D. Development of new probiotics Correct Option: None

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Bassler, why are bacteria important for keeping us alive?
Options: A. They cover us in an invisible body armor that keeps environmental toxins out, B. They digest our food, C. They make our vitamins, D. They keep bad microbes out of our immune system, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are bacteria, and how long have they been on Earth? Options: A. Bacteria are multicellular organisms that have been on Earth for millions of years., B. Bacteria are single-celled microscopic organisms that have been on Earth for billions of years., C. Bacteria are single-celled organisms that have been on Earth for thousands of years., D. Bacteria are multicellular organisms that have been on Earth for billions of years. Correct Option: None
Question 2: How do bacteria make a living? Options: A. They consume nutrients from the environment, grow to twice their size, and then shrink back down., B. They consume nutrients from the environment, grow to twice their size, cut themselves down in the middle, and one cell becomes two., C. They consume nutrients from the environment and remain the same size., D. They produce their own nutrients and grow to twice their size. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the approximate ratio of bacterial cells to human cells in the human body? Options: A. 1:1, B. 10:1, C. 1:10, D. 100:1 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the bacterium that has a special property of making light? Options: A. Vibrio fischeri, B. Escherichia coli, C. Staphylococcus aureus, D. Bacillus subtilis Correct Option: None
Question 5: How do bacteria communicate with each other? Options: A. Through a complex system of nerves, B. Through a chemical language, C. Through sound waves, D. Through electromagnetic signals Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the process by which bacteria communicate with each other and coordinate their behavior? Options: A. Quorum sensing, B. Chemotaxis, C. Symbiosis, D. Mutualism Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the purpose of the molecule produced by Vibrio fischeri? Options: A. To attract predators, B. To communicate with other bacteria, C. To produce light, D. To defend against competitors Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the squid that has a symbiotic relationship with Vibrio fischeri? Options: A. Hawaiian bobtail squid, B. Giant squid, C. Colossal squid, D. Market squid Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the purpose of the anti-quorum sensing molecules developed by the researcher? Options: A. To promote the growth of beneficial bacteria, B. To inhibit the growth of pathogenic bacteria, C. To enhance the virulence of bacteria, D. To disrupt the communication between bacteria Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential application of the anti-quorum sensing molecules? Options: A. Development of new antibiotics, B. Development of new vaccines, C. Development of new diagnostic tools, D. Development of new probiotics Correct Option: None

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: During Bassler's research, it was discovered that a bacterium called Vibrio fischeri living in the Hawaiian Bobtail Squid had a special property to make light during what times?
Options: A. When they grew to a certain cell number in a community, B. When they were alone, C. When they were reproducing, D. When they died
Correct Option: A

Question 1: What are bacteria, and how long have they been on Earth? Options: A. Bacteria are multicellular organisms that have been on Earth for millions of years., B. Bacteria are multicellular organisms that have been on Earth for billions of years. Correct Option: None
Question 2: How do bacteria make a living? Options: A. They consume nutrients from the environment, grow to twice their size, and then shrink back down., B. They consume nutrients from the environment, grow to twice their size, cut themselves down in the middle, and one cell becomes two., C. They consume nutrients from the environment and remain the same size., D. They produce their own nutrients and grow to twice their size. Correct Option: None

Question 4: What is the name of the bacterium that has a special property of making light? Options: A. Vibrio fischeri, B. Escherichia coli, C. Staphylococcus aureus, D. Bacillus subtilis Correct Option: None
Question 5: How do bacteria communicate with each other? Options: A. Through a complex system of nerves, B. Through a chemical language, C. Through sound waves, D. Through electromagnetic signals Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the process by which bacteria communicate with each other and coordinate their behavior? Options: A. Quorum sensing, B. Chemotaxis, C. Symbiosis, D. Mutualism Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the purpose of the molecule produced by Vibrio fischeri? Options: A. To attract predators, B. To communicate with other bacteria, C. To produce light, D. To defend against competitors Correct Option: None

To inhibit the growth of pathogenic bacteria, C. To enhance the virulence of bacteria, D. To disrupt the communication between bacteria Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential application of the anti-quorum sensing molecules? Options: A. Development of new antibiotics, B. Development of new vaccines, C. Development of new diagnostic tools, D. Development of new probiotics Correct Option: None

counted and then everybody responds to the vote and what's important for today's talk is that we know that there are hundreds of behaviors that bacteria carry out in these collective fashions but the **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In Bassler's talk, she mentions that when bacteria "talk" to each other and launch their virulent attack together, they are successful in overcoming a large host. What is this process called?
Options: A. System meltdown, B. Ambush, C. Quorum sensing, D. High cell density
Correct Option: C

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When Rob McEwen’s geologists were having difficulty identifying the presence and location of the gold in his mines, what radical approach did he take?
Options: A. Fired his geologists and hired computer scientists, B. Released his data and held the Goldcorp Challenge, C. Released his data and held the Goldcorp Challenge, D. Trained his staff to develop 3D animations of his mine, E. Decided to mine silver instead
Correct Option: B

Question: What happens to power structures as knowledge becomes increasingly distributed?
Options: A. Power becomes centralized, B. Power becomes decentralized, C. Power becomes concentrated into tiny oligopolies, D. Power exhibits a hierarchical structure, E. Power becomes controlled by extremists
Correct Option: B

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Don, the internet did not give rise to an information age, but instead gave rise to:
Options: A. The Agrarian Age, B. The Industrial Age, C. The Open Age, D. The Social Media Age, E. The Age of Networked Intelligence
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the speaker's definition of openness in the context of the technology revolution? Options: A. The ability to access information on the internet, B. Question 7: What is the principle of openness that involves giving up assets and intellectual property? Options: A. Collaboration, B. Transparency, C. Sharing, D. Empowerment Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Have you heard the one about Thomas Jefferson and the Louisiana Territory? Thomas Jefferson, author of The Declaration of Independence, was not a fan of the new constitution presented in 1787. He was very worried that The Constitution gave too much power to the new, national government, and not enough power to the states, an issue known as "big government". Jefferson only reluctantly agreed to support it when his friend, James Madison, promised to propose a bill of rights after it was ratified. But Jefferson's fears about big government did not go away. For example, Secretary of the Treasury, Alexander Hamilton, proposed a national bank in 1790, and Jefferson knew there was no provision in The Constitution to permit such a thing. Hamilton claimed some sort of implied powers mumbo-jumbo. Sure, it wasn't written in The Constitution, but The Constitution implied that it could be done. But, Jefferson wasn't buying it. Nonetheless, the bank was established by Hamilton and President Washington. When Jefferson was sworn in as President in 1801, he pledged to reduce the size and scope of the national government. But, of course, things didn't go exactly as he had planned. Spain secretly transferred the Louisiana Territory to France right beneath Jefferson's nose. When Congress found out, they quickly began discussions with France to buy a piece of the territory along the Mississippi River for about $2 million. But, there was one little problem: Jefferson knew there was no provision in The Constitution to buy foreign territory. So what was a strict constructionist to do? First, he tried to get an amendment to The Constitution passed that would expressly permit the purchase, but Congress wasn't willing to do it. Then, without permission, the U.S. negotiators in France cut a deal for all of the territory for a cool $15 million dollars. That new land doubled the size of the nation! Now Jefferson was really stuck. He knew that the territory would be a great acquisition for the country, providing lots of new land for farmers and other settlers, but how could he constitutionally justify it? In the end, Jefferson turned to the argument used by his old foe Alexander Hamilton. He claimed that the power to purchase the territory is implied in The Constitution's treaty-making power. This was the exact argument that he had mocked openly a decade before, so it must have crushed his pride to have to use it. But more importantly, he may have committed the biggest big government play ever! How ironic is it that one of the biggest opponents of big government doubled the size of the young country and did so while openly questioning its constitutionality? At $15 million, which is about three cents an acre, it has been called by many the greatest real estate deal in the history of the United States.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In 1790, Thomas Jefferson opposed the creation of the National Bank because
Options: A. It was not expressly authorized by the Constitution, B. It failed to benefit his home state of Virginia, C. Treasury Secretary Hamilton refused to put Washington’s face on the $1 bill, D. It symbolized small government
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the author of The Declaration of Independence? Options: A. James Madison, B. Alexander Hamilton, C. Thomas Jefferson, D. George Washington Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was Thomas Jefferson's main concern about the new constitution presented in 1787? Options: A. It did not give enough power to the national government, B. It did not provide a bill of rights, C. It gave too much power to the national government and not enough to the states, D. It did not establish a national bank Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why did Thomas Jefferson agree to support the new constitution? Options: A. Because James Madison promised to propose a bill of rights after it was ratified, B. Because Alexander Hamilton promised to establish a national bank, C. Because George Washington promised to reduce the size and scope of the national government, D. Because he believed it was perfect as it was Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who proposed a national bank in 1790? Options: A. Thomas Jefferson, B. James Madison, C. Alexander Hamilton, D. George Washington Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did Thomas Jefferson oppose the national bank proposed by Alexander Hamilton? Options: A. Because he believed it was too expensive, B. Because he believed it was not necessary, C. Because he believed there was no provision in The Constitution to permit it, D. Because he believed it would reduce the size and scope of the national government Correct Option: None
Question 6: What event occurred in 1801 that affected Thomas Jefferson's plans to reduce the size and scope of the national government? Options: A. The Louisiana Territory was transferred from Spain to France, B. The national bank was established, C. The Declaration of Independence was signed, D. The Constitution was ratified Correct Option: None
Question 7: How much did the U.S. negotiators in France agree to pay for the Louisiana Territory? Options: A. $2 million, B. $5 million, C. $10 million, D. $15 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was Thomas Jefferson's initial approach to justifying the purchase of the Louisiana Territory? Options: A. He claimed that the power to purchase the territory was implied in The Constitution's treaty-making power, B. He tried to get an amendment to The Constitution passed that would expressly permit the purchase, C. He believed that the territory was not worth purchasing, D. He believed that the purchase was unconstitutional Correct Option: None
Question 9: What argument did Thomas Jefferson eventually use to justify the purchase of the Louisiana Territory? Options: A. He claimed that the power to purchase the territory was implied in The Constitution's treaty-making power, B. He believed that the territory was not worth purchasing, C. He believed that the purchase was unconstitutional, D. He claimed that the power to purchase the territory was explicitly stated in The Constitution Correct Option: None
Question 10: What has the purchase of the Louisiana Territory been called by many? Options: A. The biggest mistake in U.S. history, B. The greatest real estate deal in the history of the United States, C. A waste of taxpayer money, D. A constitutional crisis Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about Thomas Jefferson's opposition to the national bank proposed by Alexander Hamilton, and both questions have an option that states Jefferson's opposition was due to the lack of a provision in the Constitution to permit the bank. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Have you heard the one about Thomas Jefferson and the Louisiana Territory? Thomas Jefferson, author of The Declaration of Independence, was not a fan of the new constitution presented in 1787. He was very worried that The Constitution gave too much power to the new, national government, and not enough power to the states, an issue known as "big government". Jefferson only reluctantly agreed to support it when his friend, James Madison, promised to propose a bill of rights after it was ratified. But Jefferson's fears about big government did not go away. For example, Secretary of the Treasury, Alexander Hamilton, proposed a national bank in 1790, and Jefferson knew there was no provision in The Constitution to permit such a thing. Hamilton claimed some sort of implied powers mumbo-jumbo. Sure, it wasn't written in The Constitution, but The Constitution implied that it could be done. But, Jefferson wasn't buying it. Nonetheless, the bank was established by Hamilton and President Washington. When Jefferson was sworn in as President in 1801, he pledged to reduce the size and scope of the national government. But, of course, things didn't go exactly as he had planned. Spain secretly transferred the Louisiana Territory to France right beneath Jefferson's nose. When Congress found out, they quickly began discussions with France to buy a piece of the territory along the Mississippi River for about $2 million. But, there was one little problem: Jefferson knew there was no provision in The Constitution to buy foreign territory. So what was a strict constructionist to do? First, he tried to get an amendment to The Constitution passed that would expressly permit the purchase, but Congress wasn't willing to do it. Then, without permission, the U.S. negotiators in France cut a deal for all of the territory for a cool $15 million dollars. That new land doubled the size of the nation! Now Jefferson was really stuck. He knew that the territory would be a great acquisition for the country, providing lots of new land for farmers and other settlers, but how could he constitutionally justify it? In the end, Jefferson turned to the argument used by his old foe Alexander Hamilton. He claimed that the power to purchase the territory is implied in The Constitution's treaty-making power. This was the exact argument that he had mocked openly a decade before, so it must have crushed his pride to have to use it. But more importantly, he may have committed the biggest big government play ever! How ironic is it that one of the biggest opponents of big government doubled the size of the young country and did so while openly questioning its constitutionality? At $15 million, which is about three cents an acre, it has been called by many the greatest real estate deal in the history of the United States.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When Thomas Jefferson was elected president in 1800, he pledged to
Options: A. Purchase the Louisiana Territory, B. Enlarge the size of the National Bank, C. Reduce the size and scope of the federal government, D. Fight Napoleon for the Louisiana Territory
Correct Option: C
